column1: == Climate ==
Although located some distance north of the geographic tropics
column2: Hamilton has a warm trade-wind tropical rainforest climate (Af) bordering on humid subtropical climate (Cfa). It is warm enough for coconut palms and other tropical palms to grow
column3: although they may not fruit properly due to the lack of heat or sunshine during the winter months because of latitude. Hamilton has uncharacteristically warm temperatures for its latitude (32°N) because of the moderating influence of the North Atlantic and nearby Gulf Stream. Hamilton features warm and humid summers and semi-warm "winters". As temperatures are moderated by the Atlantic Ocean
column4: it rarely gets very hot or cold in the city. Precipitation is plentiful throughout the year and Hamilton does not have a dry season month
column5: a month where on average less than 60 mm (2.36 in) of precipitation falls. Summer precipitation is usually from showers
column7: and tropical disturbances or even tropical cyclones. Meanwhile
column8: winter precipitation is typically derived from westerly moving extra-tropical cyclones and their associated fronts. Erratic
column9: extended dry spells occasionally develop because of variations in the semi-permanent sub-tropical ridge locally known as the Bermuda-Azores High.

column1: The highlight of the sports calendar is the Bermuda Gold Cup (or Argo Group Gold Cup as it is known)
column2: a sailing event which is a key stage of the World Match Racing Tour
column3: one of only three sailing championships to be sanctioned by the International Sailing Federation (ISAF) with 'Special Event' status. The Argo Cup brings the world's best match-racing sailors (including world champions and Olympic sailors) to Bermuda for five days of one-on-one 'match racing'. Points accrued during the event contribute to the World Match Racing Tour and ultimately a chance to race in the final event
column4: the Monsoon Cup in Malaysia. The winner of that is crowned ISAF World Match Racing Champion. Unlike many water-based sports
column5: which occur too far out to view from shore
column6: 'match racing' is a great spectator sport. The race takes place only 15m from the shore
column7: and spectators can see the heart of the action.

column1: The history of the modern Bermuda Gold Cup event dates back to the very beginning of the match racing style of sailing. The first 'match race' in a one-design racing yacht
column3: was the King Edward VII Gold Cup in Bermuda (now known as the Argo Gold Cup) that was first sailed in 1937. The Argo Gold Cup is still a key event in the World Match Racing Tour calendar.

column1: The King Edward VII Cup itself was originally given at the Tri-Centenary Regatta at Jamestown
column4: by King Edward VII in commemoration of the 300th Anniversary of the first permanent settlement in America. C. Sherman Hoyt won that regatta
column5: and was the first sailor to accept the historic trophy.

column1: Hoyt held the Gold Cup for three decades before donating it to the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club and proposing an annual one-on-one match-race series in 6-Meter yachts. In his letter he expressed the propriety of "my returning a British Royal trophy to the custody of your club
column2: with its long record of clean sportsmanship and keenly contested races between your Bermuda yachts and ours of Long Island Sound
column3: and elsewhere..." The first winner of the Cup in its new format was Briggs Cunningham in 1937. He was also the first skipper to win the America's Cup in a 12-Meter racing yacht.
